questions.text: A 20 year old child presented with patchy alopecia and nail findings as shown. What is the diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
• Patchy alopecia can be alopecia areata, tinea capitis or trichotillomania.
  • However, nail findings shown in the question are - superficial, fine, regular pitting which is typically seen in alopecia areata.
  • Therefore the diagnosis of alopecia areata can be considered
  • Trichotillomania is not associated with such nail findings
  • Further, in a 20 year old - tinea capitis is not considered as it is rare after puberty.
  • Other rare cause can be moth eaten alopecia which is seen in secondary syphilis and other findings like asymptomatic skin rash, coppery brown scaly m acules on palms/soles, condyloma lata in genitalia. Past history of painless genital ulcer may be present
  • Psoriasis shows coarse irregular deep nail pitting and lesion on skin may be present. Not associated with patchy alopecia

questions.text: A 20 year old obese girl with irregular menstrual cycle, presented with lesions as shown. All the following can be used in treatment except ?
questions.solution:
In a 20 year old obese girl with irregular menstrual cycle and image showing hirsutism & acne - diagnosis of hyperandrogenism should be considered and evaluation for the Same should be done.

In the treatment

  1. Drugs for management of acne: oral antibiotics like doxy/minocycline, isotetinoin
  2. Drugs for hyperandrogenism: cyproterone, OCPs, spironolactone, flutamide, bicalutamide
  3. Danazol - anabolic steroid with androgenic side effects is not indicated

questions.text: The mother brought her 8 month old infant with complaints of multiple itchy, eczematous, exudative lesions on the body since 2 weeks. Similar lesions are also seen in elder brother. the most probable diagnosis is
questions.solution:
• Infantile scabies presents with itchy lesions on full body, vesiculo-pustules on palms and soles, and crusting
  • In addition, the face and scalp area may also be involved, which are usually spared in older children and adults.
  • the combination of a pruritic eruption with characteristic manifestations, and family involvement are usually sufficient to establish the diagnosis
  • Treatment consists of application of 5% permethrin cream at bedtime to all skin surfaces in infants and from the neck down in older family members; it should be washed off after 8~14 hours.
  • Other drugs used in infantile scabies: benzyl-benzoate, crotamiton, sulfur
  • Other options
    • Congenital syphilis - can have vesicular lesions on palms/soles but they are not itchy. Along with that - rhinitis, hepatosplenomegaly, periostitis may be seen. Also, history of syphilis in mother might be seen
    • Impetigo: golden yellow honey colored crusting
    • Infantile eczema: may show itchy lesions but such pustules are not present

questions.text: A farmer having trauma on lower limb 6 months back now develops lesion on the foot as shown. The Biopsy findings reveal thick walled, brown, round bodies. What is the diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
• Chromoblastomycosis -
  • Org: Fonsecaea pedrosoi, Phialophora verrucosa, Cladosporium carrionii,Fonsecaea compacta
  • Verrucous rough surface nodules and exophytic swellings over the foot
  • Biopsy shows copper penny bodies (thick walled, brown, round bodies)
  • Other options:
    • Sporotrichosis: Linear nodulo-ulcerative lesions in lymphoid distribution
    • Mycetoma: It is characterized by triad of painless swelling, sinuses, pus discharge containing granules (aggregates of the causative organisms)
    • Tuberculosis verrucosa cutis: single, well defined verrucous lesion with sero-purulent discharge. Biopsy will show granuloma

questions.text: A HIV positive adult male presented with hilar lymphadenopathy and lung involvement presented with lesions on face as shown. CBNAAT was negative. What is the diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
• In a HIV patient, there can be many differentials of umbilicated lesions on skin.
  • However, Umbilicated lesions on the skin + pulmonary complaints points towards a diagnosis of histoplasmosis.
  • Histoplasmosis is a granulomatous infection caused by Histoplasma capsulatum, a dimorphic fungus.
  • Pulmonary involvement is the most common clinical presentation.
  • Cutaneous manifestations are reported to occur in 10% to 25% of AIDS patients with disseminated histoplasmosis.
  • The skin lesions are polymorphic papules, plaques pustules, nodules, mucosal ulcers.
  • Characteristic and often confusing lesions - lesions resembling molluscum contagiosum, umbilicated papules

questions.text: A patient with history of single hypoaesthetic lesion on face now presents with redness and edema over the lesion. Examination shows poor eyelid closure and reduced lacrimation. What will be the approach to treatment?
questions.solution:
• history of single hypoaesthetic lesion on face - diagnosis of leprosy
  • redness and edema over the lesion - type 1 reaction
  • poor eyelid closure and reduced lacrimation - facial nerve neuritis
  • Treatment: MBMDT with steroids

questions.text: A patient had recurrent oral lesions and painful superficial eruptions in genital area. A biopsy of the vesicular lesions was done. What is the best treatment option for this patient?
questions.solution:
• Recurrent oral and genital eruptions can be seen in multiple diseases, most important causes being herpes and Behcets disease
  • The biopsy image: multinucleate giant cells, ballooning degeneration and acantholysis goes in favour of herpes as the diagnosis
  • HSV 1 and 2 - both viruses can cause recurrent oro-genital painful eruptions
  • Treatment: aciclovir

questions.text: A 28 week pregnant lady came with lesions as shown. What is the appropriate treatment ?
questions.solution:
• Diagnosis: Anogenital warts / condyloma acuminata.
  • MC cause HPV-6.
  • C/F: soft, pink, elongated and sometimes filiform or pedunculated lesions
  • In women, growth can be enhanced during pregnancy.
  • Treatment
  • Podophyllin, imiquimod, sinecatechins, surgical
  • In pregnancy: cryotherapy, Tca appl

questions.text: A woman presents with malodorous vaginal discharge. The cervix appears normal on examination and the smear findings are shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
• This patient has bacterial vaginosis (BV)
  • Amsel criteria. Three out of four criteria are needed:
    1. thin, white, and homogeneous vaginal discharge
    2. clue cells > 20 %
    3. pH of vaginal fluid more than 4.5
    4. release of a fishy odour on adding alkali (10% KOH), also known as a positive whiff test.
  • Treatment regimens include oral metronidazole (500 mg twice daily for 5-7 days, or 2 g single dose)

a. Trichomoniasis: greenish frothy discharge, strawberry cervix. Motile flagellates in wet mount

b. Candidiasis: itching with curdy white discharge, pseudohyphae on KOH

c. Chlamydiasis: mucopurulent cervical discharge, PMNs in cervical smear gram stain

questions.text: A 35 year old male patient presented with 10 year history of erythematous skin lesions with micaceous scaling. He has now developed pain and stiffness in fingers and knee. All of the following inflammatory pathways can be targeted in management of the patient except
questions.solution:
• Erythematous skin lesions with micaceous scaling - s/o psoriasis
  • Pain and stiffness in fingers and knee - s/o diagnosis of psoriatic arthritis. In 70% patients, PSA develops after many years of psoriasis
  • Management of Ps + PSA in a patient
    1. Methotrexate
    2. Leflunomide
    3. Ciclosporine
    4. Biologics:
      • Tnf alpha inh - Adalimumab, Etanercept, Infliximab, Certolizumab pegol, Golimumab
      • IL 17 inh - Secukinumab, Ixekizumab
      • IL 12/23 inh - Ustekinumab
      • IL 23 inh - Guselkumab, Risankizumab, Tildrakizumab
      • PDE4 inh - Apremilast
      • JAK inh - Tofacitinib, Upadacitinib

questions.text: Patient with orange skin, palmoplantar keratoderma, keratotic follicular papules on hands and histopathology showing alternating ortho-parakeratosis. What is the diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
• The classic sequence of signs in Pityriasis rubra pilaris (PRP)begins with a diffuse fine scale seen on the scalp.
  • Within weeks to months, lesions increase in a cephalocaudal pattern
  • Characteristic orange-red hyperkeratotic follicular papules are prominent both within the patches of erythema and within adjoining areas of uninvolved skin (nutmeg grater papules)
  • Orange erythroderma with "islands of sparing" or "skip areas."
  • Another characteristic finding : unique red-orange waxy palmoplantar keratoderma (PPK) so-called "sandal-like" PPK
  1. Lichen planus : Purple, pruritic papules
  2. Keratosis follicularis : Darier disease,previously known as keratosis follicularis, is a genodermatosis inherited in an autosomal dominant fashion, classically featuresmultiple red or brown, warty papules on face, neck, nail abnormalities(eg, longitudinal erythronychia), and mucosal changes (cobblestone papules)
  3. Keratosis pilaris : Keratosis pilaris first appears in early childhood and progresses, becoming most extensive during the second decade of life. It is associated with many other conditions, including atopic dermatitis, ichthyosis vulgaris. This asymptomatic eruption generally occurs on the extensor surfaces of the proximal upper and lower extremities as well as the buttocks as ref follicular papules

questions.text: A patient with presented with severe oral ulcers since 3 months and flaccid bullae with painful red raw erosions on the skin. Direct immunofluorescence findings are shown. Characteristic microscopic feature of this disease is:
questions.solution:
• history of flaccid bullae and fishnet appearance on DIF give us a hint of the disease being pemphigus. Now we have to chose between pemphigus vulgaris and foliaceous.
  • Presence of oral ulcers rules out P. foliaceous
  • The diagnosis is pemphigus vulagris which characteristically shows supra-basal split

  • Subepidermal split-Bullous pemphigoid, linear IgA disease, dermatitis herpetiformis
  • Epidermal necrosis -toxic epidermal necrosis

questions.text: A 28 yr old patient with history of chronic diarrhoea, presents with multiple grouped papulovesicular lesions and excoriations on elbow, knees, buttocks and upper back. Histopathology findings are shown below. Which of the following systemic disease may be associated ?
questions.solution:
• Multiple grouped papulovesicular lesions and excoriations on elbow, knees, buttocks and upper back - s/o vesiculobullous disease, itching goes in favour of subepidermal disorders
  • Image given Histopathology : subepidermal blister with neutrophilic papillary tip abcesses
  • Diagnosis of Dermatitis Herpetiformis
  • Chronic diarrhoea in these patients may be due to associated coeliac disease
  • Dermatitis Herpetiformis
  • Associated with:
  • Gluten sensitive enteropathy/ Coeliac disese
  • HLA - B8 / DRw3 & HLA DQW2
  • IgA autoantibodies against epidermal transglutaminase & granular deposits of IgA in papillary dermis.
  • C/F - Intensely pruritic, papulovesicular lesions, symmetrically distributed over extensor surfaces (i.e. elbows, knees, buttocks, back scalp & posterior neck)
  • No mucosal involvement
  • HPE : subepidermal blister with neutrophilic papillary tip abcesses.
  • DIF - granular deposits of IgA along the basement membrane zone.
  • DOC : Dapsone, gluten - free diet.

questions.text: A 9 old year child presents with recurrent itchy rash over body. There is history of bronchial asthma in mother. What is the diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
• Atopic eczema (atopic dermatitis) is a chronic, relaping-remitting inflammatory skin condition characterized by severe itching, redness, oozing, swollen and cracked skin
  • It typically starts in childhood with changing severity over the years.
  • Itching is an essential feature
  • Personal/family h/o atopy generally present : asthma/allergic rhinitis/food allergy/chronic urticaria
  • Cause is unknown but involve genetics (fillagrin deficiency), immune system dysfunction, environmental exposures and skin barrier dysfunction

questions.text: A 35 year old lady with history of hairdye application presents with the following clinical picture. What is the cause ?
questions.solution:
• Clinically, hair dye dermatitis can present as severe clinical contact reactions ranging from anaphylaxis to oedema of the scalp, face, and eyelids.
  • Scalp, scalp margins, face are the reported sites that are commonly affected due to hair dye usage
  • Hands may be affected among persons not using gloves while dying hair.
  • Mild to moderate contact reactions such as erythema, oozing, and ulceration typically at the scalp margin, and on the ears, face and neck are common as a result of direct contact.
  • p-phenylenediamine (PPD) remains the most commonly implicated agent
  • Paratertiary butyl phenol - bindi
  • Potassium dichromate - cement
  • Sesquiterpenlactones - Air borne contact dermatitis

questions.text: A 18 yr male presented with pigmentation over shoulder for the last 2 years as shown in image . What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Beckers nevus : benign, late-onset type of epidermal nevus.
  • Androgen dependent : Develops around puberty, hypertrichosis, and acneiform lesions
  • MC site : shoulder, scapular area, and the upper arms
  • It presents as a well-defined, unilateral, hyperpigmented tan or brown patch with geographic pattern margins.
  • Significant hair growth over the lesions is usually seen
  • Treatment ( cosmetic purposes):- Q switched NDYAG laser
  • Congenital melanocytic nevus : characterized by benign proliferations of nevomelanocytes and presents at birth as well-defined round or ovoid lesions with a smooth surface and uniform brown black color. Hypertrichosis on surface. Long term risk of malignant melanoma in giant nevi
  • Nevus of Ito : Congenital, flat blue grey lesions on acromio-clavicular area (Dermal melanocytosis)
  • Café-au-lait macule : present at birth or appear in early childhood as flat, light to dark brown hyperpigmented macule

questions.text: A 70 year old lady patient presents with this lesion over face since 2 years. Histopathology shows peripheral palisading. What is the diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
• Basal cell carcinoma most commonly appears as a pearly shiny lesion with typical rolled out borders, prominent telangiectatias, bleeds on erosion.
  • Pigmented BCC can be darker in color due to presence of melanin
  • Pigmented BCC can be confused and misdiagnosed as malignant melanoma because of hyperpigmentation; however, pigmented BCC is marked by its firm consistency, translucence, rolled up borders and occasional surface ulceration
  • Squamous cell carcinoma most commonly appears as a firm, smooth, or hyperkeratotic papule or plaque, often with central ulceration
  • Melano-acanthoma : benign epithelial lesion that typically presents as a solitary , slow growing black plaque or nodule, usually on either the head, neck, or trunk of an older adult in their seventh decade

questions.text: A 6 year old child from a low income household presents with frequent diarrhea, irritability, and skin rash as shown. He is currently on treatment for pulmonary kochs. What is the diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
Question-child from low income, rural area : risk of nutritional deficiency

On tt for pulmonary kochs-ATT includes drugs that can contribute to niacin deficiency

Image : casal necklace

Diagnosis of pellagra :

  • Pellagra is a nutritional disorder caused by niacin (vitamin B3) deficiency
  • characterized by the 4 D's:Dermatitis,Diarrhea, andDementia leading toDeath
  • Skin rash : typical photosensitive distribution with well defined borders, and is mostly observed on the face, the neck - forming the so-calledCasal's necklace-the dorsa of the hands and the extensor surface of the forearms.
  • Gastrointestinal involvement - intractable diarrhea, stomatitis and glossitis,
  • neurocognitive impairment - apathy, irritability, memory loss (dementia)
  • Predisposing factors-corn/maize eaters, chronic alcoholism, malnutrition, malabsorption, drugs like isoniazid, ethionamide, 6-mercaptopurine, carcinoid syndrome

questions.text: What is the most common underlying malignancy seen in the following skin condition?
questions.solution:
Velvety pigmnentation in neck : Acanthosis nigricans

Associated Features of Acanthosis Nigricans

  • Systemic assoc : Obesity, Diabetes mellitus, Metabolic syndrome
  • Syndromes : Cushing syndrome, polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS), HAIR -AN syndrome - HAIR-AN-a syndrome of hyperandrogenism(HA), insulin resistance (IR) and acanthosis nigricans(AN)
  • Drugs : Nicotinic acid,, Corticosteroids, Oral contraceptives
  • Malignancy : Gastric adenocarcinoma
  • Acanthosis nigricans is a velvety, darkening of the skin that usually occurs in intertriginous areas. This hyperpigmentation has poorly defined borders, usually occurs in skin fold areas, such as the back of the neck, axilla, and groin, and may include thickening of the skin.
  • Etiology
  • Increased circulating insulin that activates IGF-1 which may lead to keratinocyte and dermal fibroblast proliferation.
  • Obesity
  • Diabetes mellitus
  • Medications associated Acanthosis nigricans - nicotinic acid, systemic glucocorticoids, combined oral contraceptive pill, growth hormone therapy,
  • hyperandrogenemia,PCOD
  • Malignant Acanthosis nigricans syndrome:Is associated with gastrointestinal adenocarcinomas. Malignancy-associated acanthosis nigricans usuallyhas a rapid onset and is accompanied by skin tags, multiple seborrheic keratoses (sign of Leser-Trelat), or tripe palms.

questions.text: A 60 year old diabetic lady presented with asymptomatic lesion shown in the image below ?
questions.solution:
• Granuloma annulare
  • Annular lesions with beaded papules on margins
  • Asymptomatic
  • Seen commonly in Diabetic patient
  • Palisading granuloma on HPE (most important)
  • B. Tinea Corporis : Itchy red annular plaque with scaling, vesiculo-pustules
  • C.Lupus vulgaris : painless, solitary reddish brown plaque with active margins and scarring in centre
  • D. Pityriasis rosea : initial herald patch followed by multiple lesions in Christmas tree pattern. Red annular plaques with peripheral collarette of scaling
